newsitem.title: USA: U.S. traders frustrated by Toronto bourse halt.
newsitem.headline: U.S. traders frustrated by Toronto bourse halt.

text.p: U.S. trading in Canadian stocks was dampened by the halt of the Toronto Stock Exchange's computer trading system Tuesday, frustrated U.S. traders said.
"It's a little frustrating, but I guess as the technology up there picks up it should go away," said Brad Marks, vice president of international trading at Jefferies and Co.

He added that trade in Canadian shares listed on both U.S. and Canadian exchanges had slackened following the halt of the system at 1054 EST/1554 GMT. Investors were reluctant to take positions with the Toronto exchange halted.

The exchange's computer stoppage coincided with a big volume of deals in troubled Bre-X Minerals Ltd. Almost 7.8 million Bre-X shares changed hands in the 22 minutes between its 1032 EST/1532 GMT opening and its halt on the Toronto exchange.
The exchange resumed trading as of 1145 EST/1645 GMT. However, Bre-X was not expected to resume Toronto trade before 1300 EST/1800 GMT.
"Bre-X -- if I don't see that one again it'll be too soon," said Frank Calta, director of trading at Anvil Institutional Services. He added that he had not held any Bre-X shares.
Calta said if he needed to circumvent the computer halt he would keep an open telephone line to a trader on the Toronto exchange's floor and buy and sell that way.
Marks said he had not traded much Bre-X Tuesday, only about 50,000 shares. He added about the halt, "It's just an overloading of the system from Bre-X."
